head.citation-title: Applications of neural networks to the satellite attitude control problem
head.abstracts: The problem of reorienting a rigid satellite is analyzed. Control architectures based on Neural Networks (NN) are developed in order to provide the system with adaptation capabilities when changes in the inertia properties occur. As a bonus, the inertia properties of the satellite can be estimated on-line. Since the mathematical model of a rigid satellite is nonlinear, the common NN approach would be to use nonlinear NN (NLNN) to approximate it. The structure of the NLNN must be defined by trial and error during the training process. This usually involves a great deal of time without any guarantee of success. On the other hand, the results of this research demonstrate that the full nonlinear problem can be solved utilizing linear NN (LNN), which can be designed rather than trained. The design takes advantage of the decoupling of the dynamics from the kinematics in the model structure and follows an inverse-dynamics control approach. The designed LNN receives angular velocity commands and generates the corresponding torque inputs. To cope with the nonlinearities, the corresponding signals are constructed externally and then fed to the LNN. The attitude is parameterized in terms of quaternions and controlled with a proportional feedback loop.
